text: http://raa.ruby-lang.org/project/csvscan seems to Do The Right Thing, but it's completely un-gemmed. Heigh-ho, said Anthony Crowley.
@glenmaddern http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc4180 - the ABNF is unambiguous. And I could pre-parse, but then what use is the library?
if it's actually compliant to rfc4180, that'd be even better.
desperately searching for a ruby CSV library that can handle newlines in quoted strings...
@whalec retain/release in objective C is basically manual refcounting. same performance implications, just more room for bugs.
@whalec But where's this assumption that GC = more memory usage coming from, though?
@GarryDanger walk, you lazy bugger:)

20
=> 10

in 1.8, it gives 20.

fixing code so i can delete it later... corp dev is odd sometimes.
find a bug, fix a bug, find another in the process... pretty sure this is non-terminating, even assuming I'm not introducing more.
@donsbot caffeine and guns, one of y'alls gonna shoot me to death.
@joshprice hee hee, i'm going to both:) total self-indulgence.

incorrect by deconstruction

bitten by ruby scope, AGAIN. When will I learn?

@TacticalGrace that looks a lot nicer, actually. I might have a hack at that, thanks!
so, sqlite indexes its columns from zero when you're retrieving from results, but one when you're binding parameters? *head explodes*
@nkpart ok. i was secretly hoping someone would say "ho ho ho, you've missed MagicalSecretTool. Go forth and sin no more." Oldschool it is..
@atnan what do you use when you're testing your iPhone code? OCUnit is not striking me as a particularly well-engineered tool.
so the test suite crashes with a cryptic error code because of a bug in my code. I write tests _because_ it's buggy. WTF?
frustrated by unit-testing in objective-C. one thing Rails got right was sane defaults for testing.
@pigworker where life is beautiful all the time?
@whalec any change request with the word "just" in it gets an automatic bump of three story points.
@joshprice don't get me wrong, I don't care much about the iPad either, but I don't feel betrayed...

tweets about how the iPad is overrated are so overrated.
been underwater wrt the test suite for a week now... starting to get a bit scary.

@GarryDanger github upload of crazytalk bitte.
wet, tired, saddlesore. god i love riding.
@donsbot authentically australian, i'm touched. hoping to get my numbers down for tomorrow.

first ride into work - 10 minutes late, 2 flat tyres, and 1 near-death experience.
pretty sure my shiny new objective C program leaks like a sieve with extra holes.
@donsbot not at all. this is my father's axe. i have replaced the blade 5 times, and the handle 6, but it is still my father's axe...

getting kind of annoyed with "asdf' in test data.

@jamesbritt will have to see if cabal has an idea of tool dependency.
@jamesbritt however, you don't want to be forced to use a particular happy - if hubris depended on c2hs, you couldn't use the 6.10 version.
@jamesbritt also, because it's not a direct dependency (ie, the haskell code doesn't call it), cabal can't catch it. Lodge a bug...
@jamesbritt yeah, that one's a pain. You _should_ list happy in your deps if you use it, but it's so ubiquitous that a lot of people forget
@azzamallow sydney's that and humid too.
